questions.text: Identify the radiological procedure shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Enteroclysis

 

Option A:

 

Enteroclysis is a specialized radiological examination where barium is introduced directly into the small intestine via a tube to distend and evaluate it.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Proctography: A radiological test that assesses the rectal and anal function during defecation.

 

Option C. Barium enema: A barium contrast study of the large intestine that does not involve the small intestine as primarily visualized in the image.

 

Option D. Barium meal follow-through: Involves oral ingestion of barium followed by sequential X-ray imaging to track its passage through the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The image is characteristic of enteroclysis, where a tube is inserted up to the duodenojejunal flexure, and barium is injected to provide enhanced distension and visualization of the small bowel.


Barium enteroclysis is performed via a tube inserted up to DJ flexure and barium is injected to provide better distension.

 

 

Ref: Page no-276, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 3-day-old newborn baby boy is brought to the hospital with difficulty breathing, cyanosis and coughing whenever he is fed. The baby was born full-term via vaginal delivery, and his mother had an uneventful pregnancy. He had a birth weight of 2.8 kg and was discharged from the hospital after 48 hours of observation. On examination, the baby appears to be in respiratory distress, with increased work of breathing and decreased oxygen saturation levels. What would be the best contrast of choice for study?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Iohexol

 

Option A:

 

The given scenario describes a likely case of Tracheo-esophageal fistula. Non-ionic iodinated contrast (Iohexol, Iomeprol) is preferred in such cases where barium is contraindicated.

 

Iohexol is a non-ionic iodinated contrast agent appropriate for cases where there's a risk of aspiration, such as a suspected tracheo-esophageal fistula.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Water, though harmless if aspirated, does not provide sufficient contrast for detailed imaging.

 

Option C: Gadolinium is used primarily in MRI and is not suitable for fluoroscopic studies typically required for diagnosing tracheo-esophageal fistulas.

 

Option D: Barium, while commonly used for contrast studies, can cause severe complications if aspirated into the lungs and is contraindicated in suspected tracheo-esophageal fistula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the scenario of a neonate with suspected tracheo-esophageal fistula, Iohexol is the contrast of choice due to its safety profile in cases where there is a potential risk of aspiration into the lungs.

 

Ref: Page no-946, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

choices.text: Rise in Serum Creatinine by 1.5 mg in 48 hours
Rise in Serum Creatinine by 2 mg in 48 hours
Rise in Serum Creatinine by 0.5 mg in 48 hours
Rise in Serum Creatinine by 1 mg in 48 hours

questions.text: Contrast induced nephropathy is defined as:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Rise in Serum Creatinine by 0.5 mg in 48 hours

 

Explanation:

 

Contrast-induced nephropathy

 

  • Defined as the impairment of renal function within 48 hours of intravenous contrast administration measured as either:
    • 25% increase in serum creatinine from baseline
    • 0.5 mg/dL increase in absolute Serum Creatinine value
  • It should also not be attributable to any other identifiable cause of renal failure.
  • Hydration is cornerstone in prevention of contrast induced nephropathy.
  • Non-ionic dimer (Iodixanol) is the safest contrast agent of choice in patients with high risk of CIN as it is iso-osmolar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contrast-induced nephropathy is defined as a rise in serum creatinine by 0.5 mg/dL within 48 hours after contrast administration, without an alternative cause for renal impairment. It's important to ensure adequate hydration to prevent CIN, and non-ionic dimer contrast agents like Iodixanol, which are iso-osmolar, are preferred for at-risk patients.

 

Ref: Page no -948, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

choices.text: Ioxaglate is an example of ionic monomer
Ionic monomers have three iodine atoms per two particles in solution
Iohexol is a high osmolar contrast media
High osmolar contrast agents may be ionic or non-ionic

questions.text: All of the statements about contrast media are false except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ionic monomers have three iodine atoms per two particles in solution

 

Option B:

 

Ionic monomers indeed have three iodine atoms per two particles in solution, indicating a ratio that impacts osmolality.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Ioxaglate is not an example of an ionic monomer, but rather a dimer.

 

Option C: Iohexol is a non-ionic, low osmolar contrast media, not high osmolar.

 

Option D: High osmolar contrast agents are typically ionic, not non-ionic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct statement about contrast media is that ionic monomers have three iodine atoms per two particles in solution, which is a determinant of their osmolality and a factor in their classification.

 

 

Ref: Page no -946, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

choices.text: Paramagnetic material which can shorten the T1 relaxation time
Long-term studies show deposition in brain in basal ganglia in autopsy at high doses

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Gadolinium:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Can cross the BBB

 

Option C:

 

Gadolinium chelates do not cross the blood brain barrier unless the barrier is disrupted. These agents accumulate in tissues with abnormal vascularity (inflammation & malignancy) and in regions where BBB is disrupted.

 

Under normal conditions, Gadolinium chelates do not cross the intact blood-brain barrier.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Gadolinium is indeed a paramagnetic material that can shorten T1 relaxation times in MRI imaging.

 

Option B: Gadolinium is used in its chelated form to ensure safety and prevent toxicity.

 

Option D: High doses of Gadolinium have been associated with deposition in the brain, particularly in the basal ganglia, as shown in long-term studies and autopsy findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gadolinium chelates generally do not cross the intact blood-brain barrier, which is a critical consideration in their diagnostic use in MRI imaging.

 

Ref: Page no -946, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Myelography

 

Option A:

 

Myelography is the process of injecting iodinated contrast medium into the subarachnoid space.

 

Contrast agent of choice: Iohexol

 

Myelography has largely been replaced by MRI and CT but it is still sometimes performed, particularly in patients with spinal hardware precluding MRI studies.

 

Myelography is an imaging technique that involves injecting contrast medium into the subarachnoid space around the spinal cord.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Neurography – Specialized MRI technique to image peripheral nerves.

 

Option C: Fluoroscopy – Real-time X-ray imaging that is often used to guide procedures.

 

Option D: Angiography – Imaging of blood vessels using contrast media.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The image demonstrates myelography, an investigation where contrast is injected into the subarachnoid space, primarily used when MRI is contraindicated.

 

Ref: Page no -812, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: Which of the following water-soluble iodinated contrast has highest osmolality?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ionic Monomer

 

Option C:

 

Ionic Monomer typically has the highest osmolality among contrast agents due to having three iodine atoms bound to one benzene ring which dissociates into two particles in solution.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nonionic Dimer: These agents have a lower osmolality compared to ionic contrasts due to their structure.

 

Option B. Nonionic Monomer: This contrast media is lower in osmolality than ionic agents and generally preferred for its safety profile.

 

Option D. Ionic Dimer: These are ionic but generally have lower osmolality than monomeric ionic agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ionic monomer contrast agents have the highest osmolality among iodinated contrast media, which can be a consideration in their use due to potential risks of contrast-induced nephropathy and other side effects.

 

Types of Radiocontrast Media

 

 

Ref: Page no -946, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: All of the following are contrast agents used in ultrasound except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Eovist

 

Option B:

 

Eovist is the trade name of gadolinium-based contrast agent (gadolinium-EOB-DTPA) which is selectively taken up by hepatocytes, which will increase the signal intensity of normal liver parenchyma on T1-weighted images.

 

A gadolinium-based contrast agent used in MRI, not ultrasound.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Levovist: An ultrasound contrast agent used to enhance the quality of the ultrasound image.

 

Option C. Optison: Another ultrasound contrast agent, used to improve the visualization of the heart's interior structures during an echocardiogram.

 

Option D. Sonovue: An ultrasound enhancing agent used during echocardiograms and other ultrasound examinations to improve the clarity of the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eovist is not an ultrasound contrast agent; it is a gadolinium-based agent used for liver imaging in MRI studies.

 

Ref: Page no -946, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: What is the best contrast agent for the diagnosis of esophageal perforation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Iohexol

 

Option B:

 

Barium contrast is contraindicated in esophageal perforation as it causes mediastinitis.

 

Iodinated contrast is safe for suspected GI perforation or trachea-esophageal fistula where barium is contraindicated. Iohexol (low osmolar) is preferred over Gastrograffin (high-osmolar) as it has a high chance of causing aspiration pneumonitis and pulmonary edema.

 

Iohexol, a non-ionic, low osmolar contrast medium, is safer for use in suspected gastrointestinal perforations due to lower risk of severe inflammatory reactions if aspirated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Gastrograffin is a water-soluble contrast agent but has a higher osmolarity and risk of causing pneumonitis if aspirated.

 

Option C: Gadolinium is used in MRI and is not appropriate for diagnosing esophageal perforations.

 

Option D: Barium sulfate can lead to severe mediastinitis if used in the setting of esophageal perforation and is therefore contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iohexol is the contrast agent of choice for the evaluation of esophageal perforation due to its safety profile compared to high osmolar agents and barium sulfate.

 

Ref: Page no-946, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of peptic ulcer disease presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, distention, and vomiting for the past 24 hours. He reports that the pain started suddenly and has been getting progressively worse. He has not had a bowel movement or passed gas in over 12 hours. On examination, the patient appears to be in severe distress, with a distended and tender abdomen. He has a fever of 39C, and his blood pressure is low at 90/60 mmHg. Blood tests show an elevated white blood cell count. Which of the following would be detrimental in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Barium meal

 

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of perforation secondary to intestinal obstruction. Barium studies are contraindicated in this case as they lead to aggravation of peritonitis.

 

Contraindications to barium studies:

 

  • Perforation
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Post operative bowel Surgery
  • Tracheo-esophageal fistula
  • Water soluble iodinated water contrast is preferred in all of these cases

 

Barium meal is contraindicated because if there is a perforation, barium can leak into the peritoneal cavity, leading to chemical peritonitis and exacerbating the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography) can be utilized for abdominal assessment, but caution is needed regarding contrast in suspected perforation cases.

 

Option B: CECT with oral contrast may help delineate anatomy, but there's a risk if perforation is present.

 

Option C: Gastrograffin study, a water-soluble contrast study, is generally safe and can be used to identify leaks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected gastrointestinal perforation, such as with a peptic ulcer, barium contrast studies are contraindicated due to the risk of causing chemical peritonitis. Water-soluble contrast studies are preferred for their safer profile.

 

Ref: Page no -254, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

questions.text: Which of the following is a water-soluble contrast?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Iohexol

 

Option B: Iohexol – A nonionic, water-soluble iodinated contrast medium utilized in various radiographic procedures.

 

lohexol is a nonionic, water-soluble radiographic contrast medium.

 

lohexol is a nonionic, water-soluble iodinated contrast medium.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Calcium: Not used as a contrast agent in radiographic studies.

 

Option C. Bromium: Not a contrast agent; bromine is a chemical element.

 

Option D. Barium: Primarily used as a contrast agent in imaging studies of the GI tract but is not water-soluble.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iohexol is a water-soluble, nonionic iodinated contrast medium commonly used in diagnostic radiology.

 

 

Ref: Page no -946, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

questions.text: Which of the following contrast agents is used in MRI?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Omniscan

 

Option A:

 

The contrast agent used for MRI is gadolinium. It acts by reducing T1 relaxation time of the tissue. Omniscan is a tradename of Gadodiamide.

 

Omniscan is a gadolinium-based contrast agent used in MRI to enhance tissue contrast.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Omnipaque: An iodinated contrast medium used in CT scans, not in MRI.

 

Option C. Levovist: An ultrasound contrast agent, not applicable for MRI.

 

Option D. Microbar: A barium sulfate contrast agent typically used in gastrointestinal studies, not suitable for MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MRI, gadolinium-based agents like Omniscan (Gadodiamide) are used to reduce T1 relaxation time, enhancing the contrast of tissues and abnormalities.

 

Ref: Page no -946, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

questions.text: Out of the listed factors, which one is not considered a risk factor for Contrast-Induced Nephropathy (CIN)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Obesity

 

Option C:

 

Although obesity is associated with many health issues, it is not independently considered a primary risk factor for CIN.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Diabetic nephropathy: Patients with diabetic kidney disease are at increased risk of CIN.

 

Option B. High osmolar contrast agents: These agents are indeed associated with a higher risk of CIN compared to low osmolar agents.

 

Option D. Dehydration: Increases the risk of CIN due to reduced renal perfusion and concentrated contrast media.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the options provided, obesity is not traditionally recognized as a risk factor for the development of Contrast-Induced Nephropathy.

 

Ref: Page no -948, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)
